issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual description) specifies that Milkable.messageOnMilk() returns a boolean ("messageOnMilk():boolean" in the UML and: "The method messageOnMilk() should return true if milking was successful, false otherwise"). However, the solution repository defines the Milkable interface and implementations with messageOnMilk() returning a String (Milkable.java: String messageOnMilk(); Goat/Seal return strings like "Goat <name> is milked"). This mismatch between the specified return type (boolean) and the solution/template usage (String) will confuse students about the required signature and what to implement, and will likely cause test failures if the exercise tests expect a boolean.
issues.suggested_fix:
Align the return type of messageOnMilk() across all artifacts. Two options (choose one consistent approach):

Option A (match problem statement): Change the interface and implementations to return boolean.
- Update solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Milkable.java to: boolean messageOnMilk();
- Update Goat.java and Seal.java messageOnMilk() to return boolean (e.g. return true when milking succeeds). If a textual message is required for output, print it from the caller or add a separate method (e.g. getMilkMessage()).
- Ensure any code that prints the result (e.g. Main.java or tests) handles a boolean return.

Option B (match solution): Update the problem statement and UML to specify messageOnMilk() returns String and adjust the textual description to say the method should return a message (e.g. "'<Animal> <name> is milked'"), then ensure tests and templates expect/print strings.

Prefer Option A if the original intent was to teach boolean-returning milk operations (as the UML/text currently indicate). Implement the code changes in the solution and update any example usages in the template/Main to reflect the boolean return.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual spec) defines Milkable.messageOnMilk() as returning a boolean (UML: messageOnMilk():boolean; text: "should return true if milking was successful, false otherwise"), but the reference solution (and the implemented classes) use messageOnMilk() with a String return type (Milkable.java: String messageOnMilk(); Goat/Seal return textual messages like "Goat <name> is milked"). This mismatch creates a direct semantic/signature conflict: students reading the problem will implement a boolean-returning method while the provided solution and sample usage print textual messages. The discrepancy makes the mapping from the problem requirement to the template/solution ambiguous and will lead to incorrect implementations or confusion about the expected return value and behaviour.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the expected return type consistent across artifacts. Two viable fixes:
1) Align the problem statement with the solution: update the UML and textual description to declare messageOnMilk():String and describe that the method should return a textual message (e.g., "Seal <name> is milked"). This preserves the current solution implementation and sample usage that print the returned message. OR
2) Align the solution with the problem statement: change the Milkable interface and implementations to return boolean and update Goat/Seal implementations to return true/false and adjust any code that prints the result accordingly. Prefer option (1) because the solution and example Main already use and expect printable messages.
